bestBHT.bht: The jailer, having heard the preaching of Paul and Silas, becomes suddenly alarmed about his spiritual state. His unfitness to appear before God and his need for salvation flash upon his soul, leading him to cry out, What must I do to be saved? In his humility, he addresses them with reverence and eagerness, recognizing that their imprisonment was due to their overturning the common religious beliefs. The jailer's question is of utmost importance, as his sincere fear and desire for sound doctrine set him apart from superficial reactions to wonders.

Henry Alford: The circumstantiality of the account shews that some eyewitness related it.

His question connected with the words, 'the way of salvation,' of the dæmoniac in ver. 17, makes it necessary to infer, as De Wette well observes, that he had previously become acquainted with the subject of their preaching.
Sirs is literally Lords: they will not take this title to themselves, but tell him of One who was alone worthy of it.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Only one explanation of it can be given—that he had become all at once alarmed about his spiritual state, and that though, a moment before, he was ready to plunge into eternity with the guilt of self-murder on his head, without a thought of the sin he was committing and its awful consequences, his unfitness to appear before God, and his need of salvation, now flashed full upon his soul and drew from the depths of his spirit the cry here recorded.
If still it be asked how it could take such definite shape, let it be considered [that] the jailer could hardly be ignorant of the nature of the charges on which these men had been imprisoned.

Then would flash across him the light of a new discovery; 'That was a true cry which the Pythoness uttered, 'These men are the servants of the most high God, which show unto us the way of salvation! That I now must know, and from them, as divinely sent to me, must I learn that way of salvation!'
Albert Barnes: Never was a more important question asked than this.
The feelings of an awakened sinner are often strikingly similar to those of this jailor.
In this narrative we see the contrast which exists in periods of distress and alarm between Christians and sinners.
John Calvin: He demandeth how he may obtain salvation; whereby it appeareth more plainly that he was not suddenly taken with some light fear of God only, but truly humbled to offer himself to be a scholar to his ministers.
He knew that they were cast in prison for no other cause, save only because they did overthrow the common estate of religion. Now he is ready to hear their doctrine which he had before contemned.

The wicked oftentimes when they see wonders, though they tremble for a time, yet are they straightway made more obstinate... But in this place the keeper (acknowledging the power of God) was not only a little afraid...but he showeth himself obedient to God, and desirous of sound and wholesome doctrine.
Philip Schaff: Sirs, what must I do to be saved?"
The question in the other sense appears abrupt, it is true; but we are to remember that Luke has recorded only parts of the transaction."
He comes trembling, therefore, before Paul and Silas, and asks them to tell him again more fully what he must do to be saved?
Archibald T. Robertson: He left the other prisoners inside, feeling that he had to deal with these men whom he had evidently heard preach or had heard of their message as servants of the Most High God..." (28 words)
There may have been superstition behind his fear, but there was evident sincerity." (16 words)
John Gill: he treats them with great reverence now, and addresses them under a title and character of honour and respect...
he now saw himself lost and perishing, and wanted their instructions, advice, and assistance...
his language shows, he was in earnest, and expresses great eagerness, importunity, and haste...
John Wesley: Sirs — He did not style them so the day before.
What must I do to be saved? — From the guilt I feel and the vengeance I fear?
Undoubtedly God then set his sins in array before him, and convinced him in the clearest and strongest manner that the wrath of God abode upon him.

bhtAttempts.bht: The jailer, having heard the preaching of Paul and Silas, becomes suddenly alarmed about his spiritual state. His unfitness to appear before God and his need for salvation flash upon his soul, leading him to cry out, What must I do to be saved? His fear is sincere, and he recognizes that these men, as servants of the Most High God, show unto him the way of salvation. In his humility, he addresses them with reverence and eagerness, acknowledging his guilt and the wrath of God that abides upon him. He is ready to become a student of their teachings, recognizing that their imprisonment was due to their overturning the common religious beliefs. The jailer's question is of utmost importance, and we see the contrast between the response of a sinner in distress and that of a Christian.

In his humility, he addresses them with reverence and eagerness, recognizing that their imprisonment was due to their overturning the common religious beliefs. The jailer's question is of utmost importance, and we see the contrast between the response of a sinner in distress and that of a Christian.
